Replace Instances with Code
BIOS216
Notes
New module as part of programme revalidation. Due to commence September 2025, starting with year 2.

Overview

Overview
This module will build upon basic principles of pharmacology taught in year 1 and apply them to the process of pharmaceutical research and development covering everything from target identification through to clinical trials and regulatory approval. The module will provide a holistic overview of the drug discovery and development pipeline providing insight into how pharmacological principles are applied at each stage. Students will learn about every stage of the pipeline from target identification through safety assessment, regulatory processes and post-marketing surveillance. This is a key 2nd year module which is mandatory for BSc Pharmacology and optional for other programmes. The module includes research-connected teaching in the form of lectures and workshops. Assessment will be by a multiple choice question examination (40%) and a 1500-word written examination (60%).
Educational Aims
This module aims to:
- Provide students with the basic knowledge of concepts, theories, and assays relevant to drug discovery and development.
- Prepare students for developing academic or industrial careers in drug discovery and development.
Marketing Module Synopsis
Drug discovery & development is risky: only 1 in 7 drugs entering clinical development obtained approval between 2000 and 2015. This module is designed to give students a broad understanding of the fundamental principles of drug discovery & development. The curriculum includes all important aspects of drug discovery & development, including target identification, drug design, safety assessment, clinical trials, and health economy. A highlight of this module is it will introduce some relevant mathematical modelling - (e.g., bioinformatics, computational chemistry and pharmacodynamics) which will prepare the students with necessary quantitative skills. Teaching will be via formal lectures and workshop and the module will be assessed by a multiple-choice question (MCQ) examination (40%) and written exam assessment (60%).
Outline Syllabus
1. Overview of Drug Discovery & Development
Contents:
•Biomarker, efficacy & pharmacometrics
•Drug design guidelines and fragment-based drug discovery
•Concepts for clinical development
•Case study: IRESSA
Relevant mathematical modelling topics:
•Systems Pharmacology: linking target engagement with efficacy
•PK/PD for drug repurposing
•Disease Progression Modelling
•Survival analysis
•PBPK

2. Target Identification / Validation
Contents:
•Molecular basis of disease: infection, genetic, etc
•Mechanism of action of drugs
•Types of cellular components that constitute targets
•Target ID and validation approaches
•Target ID using chemical probes
Relevant mathematical modelling topics:
•Target ID from genomes
•Target ID from systems and pathways simulations

3. Hit Generation: Drug Design and Screening
Contents:
•Drug design strategies
•Virtual screening
•Medicinal chemistry for lead optimisation
•Strategies for less druggable proteins
Relevant mathematical modelling topics:
•Structure-based drug design
•Ligand-based drug design
•Computational approaches to drug design

4. Drug Safety Biomarkers
Contents:
•Drug metabolism
•Liver toxicity

5. Preclinical Drug Safety
Contents:
•In vitro models
•Animal models
•In silico models)

6. Efficacy, PK/PD, Dose Selection
Contents:
•PK models
•PD models
•Dose selection
Relevant mathematical modelling topics:
•PK/PD
•PBPK


7. Clinical Trials and Medicines Regulation (Phase I – III)
Contents:
•Regulatory system: objectives and how it works
•Regulatory support: incentives & dialogue
•Regulatory requirements: guidelines , data / phases, reviews

Relevant mathematical modelling topics:
•First-In-Human dosage selection (PK/PD)

8. Post-Marketing Surveillance
Contents:
•Safety: Regulators
•Efficacy: Regulators (accelerated path) and health technology assessment (NICE)
•Change of labelling: ADR, warning & precaution
Relevant mathematical modelling topics:
•Real World Evidence
•Health economics and outcomes research (HEOR)
Teaching and Learning Methods
Learning and teaching throughout this module is designed and delivered by research-active scientists to ensure that teaching is informed by the latest research and best evidence (Research-connected teaching, Liverpool Curriculum Framework).

Lectures: These will cover core curriculum topics. Research focus lectures will examine areas of current interest in more detail or employability issues and opportunities related to the topic area. There will be 30x 1 hour sessions.

Workshops: these will be held with the intention of being in a flipped classroom style as an opportunity for students to gain clarity of topics and reinforcement of previous learning. There will be 2x 2 hour sessions.

In exceptional circumstances (e.g., global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE, and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

Attendance Recorded: Yes

The student directed learning element of the module will involve directed reading, accessing online resources, searching the literature and critically appraising articles. This will require adaptability & organisational skills.

Liverpool curriculum framework and the Liverpool Hallmarks are at the centre of this module as evidenced by the cohesive research connected programme we have designed where learning outcomes will be evaluated with authentic assessments that directly relate to activities performed by professional experts in the field. This module contributes to a programme which is specifically designed to support students for future training in Biosciences – employability. For example, digital fluency is taught by data analysis and the use of online platforms. Research-connected teaching is embedded in all aspects of teaching as experts in their field teach the module.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g., global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE, and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
The module will be assessed via two assessments:

The first assessment consists of a multiple choice question examination with questions covering the content delivered in syllabus items 1-3 as noted above. It is worth 40% of the module.

The second assessment will be a 1500-word written exam assessment constituting 60% of the module. This will include tasks which require the analysis and interpretation of data and information relating to clinical and/or pre-clinical case studies within a pharmaceutical discovery and development setting.

Feedback will be provided to all assessments. Pass mark for all assessments is 40%. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission of all assessments. Assessments are anonymous.

Learning materials will be available to students via the University Virtual Learning environment.

Reassessment will use the same format, but the topic or data will differ. Mark will be capped at 40%. This will take place in the normal reassessment window. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g., global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE, and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

Outcomes

Learning Outcomes
 ReferenceOutcome 
 LO1 Discuss the basic concepts and theories relevant to drug design and appraise the critical issues determining success of drug discovery and development.
 LO2 Justify the choice of different target identification methods.
 LO3 Critically discuss the relevance of basic pharmacokinetic principles to achieving a good response to therapy and critically analyse pharmacokinetic data.
 LO4 Appraise the principles of drug disposition and drug response, particularly in relation to why subjects differ in their response to drugs.
 LO5 Justify clinical trial design choices.
 LO6 Appraise quality of evidence presented to regulatory authorities and cost-benefits of drugs.
Skills

Skills

 ReferenceOutcome 
 S1 Written communication
 S2 Critical thinking
 S3 Problem solving
 S4 Biological interpretation

Contact will be made via the VLE, and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
The module will be assessed via two assessments:

The first assessment consists of a multiple choice question examination with questions covering the content delivered in syllabus items 1-3 as noted above. It is worth 40% of the module.

The second assessment will be a 1500-word written exam assessment constituting 60% of the module. This will include tasks which require the analysis and interpretation of data and information relating to clinical and/or pre-clinical case studies within a pharmaceutical discovery and development setting.

Feedback will be provided to all assessments. Pass mark for all assessments is 40%. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission of all assessments. Assessments are anonymous.

Learning materials will be available to students via the University Virtual Learning environment.

Reassessment will use the same format, but the topic or data will differ. Mark will be capped at 40%. This will take place in the normal reassessment window. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g., global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE, and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

 LO4 Appraise the principles of drug disposition and drug response, particularly in relation to why subjects differ in their response to drugs.
 LO5 Justify clinical trial design choices.
 LO6 Appraise quality of evidence presented to regulatory authorities and cost-benefits of drugs.

BIOS216
Notes
New module as part of programme revalidation. Due to commence September 2025, starting with year 2.

Overview

Overview
This module will build upon basic principles of pharmacology taught in year 1 and apply them to the process of pharmaceutical research and development covering everything from target identification through to clinical trials and regulatory approval. The module will provide a holistic overview of the drug discovery and development pipeline providing insight into how pharmacological principles are applied at each stage. Students will learn about every stage of the pipeline from target identification through safety assessment, regulatory processes and post-marketing surveillance. This is a key 2nd year module which is mandatory for BSc Pharmacology and optional for other programmes. The module includes research-connected teaching in the form of lectures and workshops. Assessment will be by a multiple choice question examination (40%) and a 1500-word written examination (60%).
Educational Aims
This module aims to:
- Provide students with the basic knowledge of concepts, theories, and assays relevant to drug discovery and development.
- Prepare students for developing academic or industrial careers in drug discovery and development.
Marketing Module Synopsis
Drug discovery & development is risky: only 1 in 7 drugs entering clinical development obtained approval between 2000 and 2015. This module is designed to give students a broad understanding of the fundamental principles of drug discovery & development. The curriculum includes all important aspects of drug discovery & development, including target identification, drug design, safety assessment, clinical trials, and health economy. A highlight of this module is it will introduce some relevant mathematical modelling - (e.g., bioinformatics, computational chemistry and pharmacodynamics) which will prepare the students with necessary quantitative skills. Teaching will be via formal lectures and workshop and the module will be assessed by a multiple-choice question (MCQ) examination (40%) and written exam assessment (60%).
Outline Syllabus
1. Overview of Drug Discovery & Development
Contents:
•Biomarker, efficacy & pharmacometrics
•Drug design guidelines and fragment-based drug discovery
•Concepts for clinical development
•Case study: IRESSA
Relevant mathematical modelling topics:
•Systems Pharmacology: linking target engagement with efficacy
•PK/PD for drug repurposing
•Disease Progression Modelling
•Survival analysis
•PBPK

2. Target Identification / Validation
Contents:
•Molecular basis of disease: infection, genetic, etc
•Mechanism of action of drugs
•Types of cellular components that constitute targets
•Target ID and validation approaches
•Target ID using chemical probes
Relevant mathematical modelling topics:
•Target ID from genomes
•Target ID from systems and pathways simulations

3. Hit Generation: Drug Design and Screening
Contents:
•Drug design strategies
•Virtual screening
•Medicinal chemistry for lead optimisation
•Strategies for less druggable proteins
Relevant mathematical modelling topics:
•Structure-based drug design
•Ligand-based drug design
•Computational approaches to drug design

4. Drug Safety Biomarkers
Contents:
•Drug metabolism
•Liver toxicity

5. Preclinical Drug Safety
Contents:
•In vitro models
•Animal models
•In silico models)

6. Efficacy, PK/PD, Dose Selection
Contents:
•PK models
•PD models
•Dose selection
Relevant mathematical modelling topics:
•PK/PD
•PBPK


7. Clinical Trials and Medicines Regulation (Phase I – III)
Contents:
•Regulatory system: objectives and how it works
•Regulatory support: incentives & dialogue
•Regulatory requirements: guidelines , data / phases, reviews

Relevant mathematical modelling topics:
•First-In-Human dosage selection (PK/PD)

8. Post-Marketing Surveillance
Contents:
•Safety: Regulators
•Efficacy: Regulators (accelerated path) and health technology assessment (NICE)
•Change of labelling: ADR, warning & precaution
Relevant mathematical modelling topics:
•Real World Evidence
•Health economics and outcomes research (HEOR)
Teaching and Learning Methods
Learning and teaching throughout this module is designed and delivered by research-active scientists to ensure that teaching is informed by the latest research and best evidence (Research-connected teaching, Liverpool Curriculum Framework).

Lectures: These will cover core curriculum topics. Research focus lectures will examine areas of current interest in more detail or employability issues and opportunities related to the topic area. There will be 30x 1 hour sessions.

Workshops: these will be held with the intention of being in a flipped classroom style as an opportunity for students to gain clarity of topics and reinforcement of previous learning. There will be 2x 2 hour sessions.

In exceptional circumstances (e.g., global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE, and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

Attendance Recorded: Yes

The student directed learning element of the module will involve directed reading, accessing online resources, searching the literature and critically appraising articles. This will require adaptability & organisational skills.

Liverpool curriculum framework and the Liverpool Hallmarks are at the centre of this module as evidenced by the cohesive research connected programme we have designed where learning outcomes will be evaluated with authentic assessments that directly relate to activities performed by professional experts in the field. This module contributes to a programme which is specifically designed to support students for future training in Biosciences – employability. For example, digital fluency is taught by data analysis and the use of online platforms. Research-connected teaching is embedded in all aspects of teaching as experts in their field teach the module.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g., global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE, and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
The module will be assessed via two assessments:

The first assessment consists of a multiple choice question examination with questions covering the content delivered in syllabus items 1-3 as noted above. It is worth 40% of the module.

The second assessment will be a 1500-word written exam assessment constituting 60% of the module. This will include tasks which require the analysis and interpretation of data and information relating to clinical and/or pre-clinical case studies within a pharmaceutical discovery and development setting.

Feedback will be provided to all assessments. Pass mark for all assessments is 40%. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission of all assessments. Assessments are anonymous.

Learning materials will be available to students via the University Virtual Learning environment.

Reassessment will use the same format, but the topic or data will differ. Mark will be capped at 40%. This will take place in the normal reassessment window. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g., global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE, and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

BIOS216
Notes
New module as part of programme revalidation. Due to commence September 2025, starting with year 2.

Overview

Overview
This module will build upon basic principles of pharmacology taught in year 1 and apply them to the process of pharmaceutical research and development covering everything from target identification through to clinical trials and regulatory approval. The module will provide a holistic overview of the drug discovery and development pipeline providing insight into how pharmacological principles are applied at each stage. Students will learn about every stage of the pipeline from target identification through safety assessment, regulatory processes and post-marketing surveillance. This is a key 2nd year module which is mandatory for BSc Pharmacology and optional for other programmes. The module includes research-connected teaching in the form of lectures and workshops. Assessment will be by a multiple choice question examination (40%) and a 1500-word written examination (60%).
Educational Aims
This module aims to:
- Provide students with the basic knowledge of concepts, theories, and assays relevant to drug discovery and development.
- Prepare students for developing academic or industrial careers in drug discovery and development.
Marketing Module Synopsis
Drug discovery & development is risky: only 1 in 7 drugs entering clinical development obtained approval between 2000 and 2015. This module is designed to give students a broad understanding of the fundamental principles of drug discovery & development. The curriculum includes all important aspects of drug discovery & development, including target identification, drug design, safety assessment, clinical trials, and health economy. A highlight of this module is it will introduce some relevant mathematical modelling - (e.g., bioinformatics, computational chemistry and pharmacodynamics) which will prepare the students with necessary quantitative skills. Teaching will be via formal lectures and workshop and the module will be assessed by a multiple-choice question (MCQ) examination (40%) and written exam assessment (60%).
Outline Syllabus
1. Overview of Drug Discovery & Development
Contents:
•Biomarker, efficacy & pharmacometrics
•Drug design guidelines and fragment-based drug discovery
•Concepts for clinical development
•Case study: IRESSA
Relevant mathematical modelling topics:
•Systems Pharmacology: linking target engagement with efficacy
•PK/PD for drug repurposing
•Disease Progression Modelling
•Survival analysis
•PBPK

2. Target Identification / Validation
Contents:
•Molecular basis of disease: infection, genetic, etc
•Mechanism of action of drugs
•Types of cellular components that constitute targets
•Target ID and validation approaches
•Target ID using chemical probes
Relevant mathematical modelling topics:
•Target ID from genomes
•Target ID from systems and pathways simulations

3. Hit Generation: Drug Design and Screening
Contents:
•Drug design strategies
•Virtual screening
•Medicinal chemistry for lead optimisation
•Strategies for less druggable proteins
Relevant mathematical modelling topics:
•Structure-based drug design
•Ligand-based drug design
•Computational approaches to drug design

4. Drug Safety Biomarkers
Contents:
•Drug metabolism
•Liver toxicity

5. Preclinical Drug Safety
Contents:
•In vitro models
•Animal models
•In silico models)

6. Efficacy, PK/PD, Dose Selection
Contents:
•PK models
•PD models
•Dose selection
Relevant mathematical modelling topics:
•PK/PD
•PBPK


7. Clinical Trials and Medicines Regulation (Phase I – III)
Contents:
•Regulatory system: objectives and how it works
•Regulatory support: incentives & dialogue
•Regulatory requirements: guidelines , data / phases, reviews

Relevant mathematical modelling topics:
•First-In-Human dosage selection (PK/PD)

8. Post-Marketing Surveillance
Contents:
•Safety: Regulators
•Efficacy: Regulators (accelerated path) and health technology assessment (NICE)
•Change of labelling: ADR, warning & precaution
Relevant mathematical modelling topics:
•Real World Evidence
•Health economics and outcomes research (HEOR)
Teaching and Learning Methods
Learning and teaching throughout this module is designed and delivered by research-active scientists to ensure that teaching is informed by the latest research and best evidence (Research-connected teaching, Liverpool Curriculum Framework).

Lectures: These will cover core curriculum topics. Research focus lectures will examine areas of current interest in more detail or employability issues and opportunities related to the topic area. There will be 30x 1 hour sessions.

Workshops: these will be held with the intention of being in a flipped classroom style as an opportunity for students to gain clarity of topics and reinforcement of previous learning. There will be 2x 2 hour sessions.

In exceptional circumstances (e.g., global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE, and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

Attendance Recorded: Yes

The student directed learning element of the module will involve directed reading, accessing online resources, searching the literature and critically appraising articles. This will require adaptability & organisational skills.

Liverpool curriculum framework and the Liverpool Hallmarks are at the centre of this module as evidenced by the cohesive research connected programme we have designed where learning outcomes will be evaluated with authentic assessments that directly relate to activities performed by professional experts in the field. This module contributes to a programme which is specifically designed to support students for future training in Biosciences – employability. For example, digital fluency is taught by data analysis and the use of online platforms. Research-connected teaching is embedded in all aspects of teaching as experts in their field teach the module.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g., global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE, and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
The module will be assessed via two assessments:

The first assessment consists of a multiple choice question examination with questions covering the content delivered in syllabus items 1-3 as noted above. It is worth 40% of the module.

The second assessment will be a 1500-word written exam assessment constituting 60% of the module. This will include tasks which require the analysis and interpretation of data and information relating to clinical and/or pre-clinical case studies within a pharmaceutical discovery and development setting.

Feedback will be provided to all assessments. Pass mark for all assessments is 40%. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission of all assessments. Assessments are anonymous.

Learning materials will be available to students via the University Virtual Learning environment.

Reassessment will use the same format, but the topic or data will differ. Mark will be capped at 40%. This will take place in the normal reassessment window. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g., global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE, and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

Outcomes

Learning Outcomes
 ReferenceOutcome 
 LO1 Discuss the basic concepts and theories relevant to drug design and appraise the critical issues determining success of drug discovery and development.
 LO2 Justify the choice of different target identification methods.
 LO3 Critically discuss the relevance of basic pharmacokinetic principles to achieving a good response to therapy and critically analyse pharmacokinetic data.
 LO4 Appraise the principles of drug disposition and drug response, particularly in relation to why subjects differ in their response to drugs.
 LO5 Justify clinical trial design choices.
 LO6 Appraise quality of evidence presented to regulatory authorities and cost-benefits of drugs.

Skills

 S2 Critical thinking
 S3 Problem solving
 S4 Biological interpretation

Replace Instances with Code
BIOS216
Notes
New module as part of programme revalidation. Due to commence September 2025, starting with year 2.

Overview

Overview
This module will build upon basic principles of pharmacology taught in year 1 and apply them to the process of pharmaceutical research and development covering everything from target identification through to clinical trials and regulatory approval. The module will provide a holistic overview of the drug discovery and development pipeline providing insight into how pharmacological principles are applied at each stage. Students will learn about every stage of the pipeline from target identification through safety assessment, regulatory processes and post-marketing surveillance. This is a key 2nd year module which is mandatory for BSc Pharmacology and optional for other programmes. The module includes research-connected teaching in the form of lectures and workshops. Assessment will be by a multiple choice question examination (40%) and a 1500-word written examination (60%).
Educational Aims
This module aims to:
- Provide students with the basic knowledge of concepts, theories, and assays relevant to drug discovery and development.
- Prepare students for developing academic or industrial careers in drug discovery and development.
Marketing Module Synopsis
Drug discovery & development is risky: only 1 in 7 drugs entering clinical development obtained approval between 2000 and 2015. This module is designed to give students a broad understanding of the fundamental principles of drug discovery & development. The curriculum includes all important aspects of drug discovery & development, including target identification, drug design, safety assessment, clinical trials, and health economy. A highlight of this module is it will introduce some relevant mathematical modelling - (e.g., bioinformatics, computational chemistry and pharmacodynamics) which will prepare the students with necessary quantitative skills. Teaching will be via formal lectures and workshop and the module will be assessed by a multiple-choice question (MCQ) examination (40%) and written exam assessment (60%).
Outline Syllabus
1. Overview of Drug Discovery & Development
Contents:
•Biomarker, efficacy & pharmacometrics
•Drug design guidelines and fragment-based drug discovery
•Concepts for clinical development
•Case study: IRESSA
Relevant mathematical modelling topics:
•Systems Pharmacology: linking target engagement with efficacy
•PK/PD for drug repurposing
•Disease Progression Modelling
•Survival analysis
•PBPK

2. Target Identification / Validation
Contents:
•Molecular basis of disease: infection, genetic, etc
•Mechanism of action of drugs
•Types of cellular components that constitute targets
•Target ID and validation approaches
•Target ID using chemical probes
Relevant mathematical modelling topics:
•Target ID from genomes
•Target ID from systems and pathways simulations

3. Hit Generation: Drug Design and Screening
Contents:
•Drug design strategies
•Virtual screening
•Medicinal chemistry for lead optimisation
•Strategies for less druggable proteins
Relevant mathematical modelling topics:
•Structure-based drug design
•Ligand-based drug design
•Computational approaches to drug design

4. Drug Safety Biomarkers
Contents:
•Drug metabolism
•Liver toxicity

5. Preclinical Drug Safety
Contents:
•In vitro models
•Animal models
•In silico models)

6. Efficacy, PK/PD, Dose Selection
Contents:
•PK models
•PD models
•Dose selection
Relevant mathematical modelling topics:
•PK/PD
•PBPK


7. Clinical Trials and Medicines Regulation (Phase I – III)
Contents:
•Regulatory system: objectives and how it works
•Regulatory support: incentives & dialogue
•Regulatory requirements: guidelines , data / phases, reviews

Relevant mathematical modelling topics:
•First-In-Human dosage selection (PK/PD)

8. Post-Marketing Surveillance
Contents:
•Safety: Regulators
•Efficacy: Regulators (accelerated path) and health technology assessment (NICE)
•Change of labelling: ADR, warning & precaution
Relevant mathematical modelling topics:
•Real World Evidence
•Health economics and outcomes research (HEOR)
Teaching and Learning Methods
Learning and teaching throughout this module is designed and delivered by research-active scientists to ensure that teaching is informed by the latest research and best evidence (Research-connected teaching, Liverpool Curriculum Framework).

Lectures: These will cover core curriculum topics. Research focus lectures will examine areas of current interest in more detail or employability issues and opportunities related to the topic area. There will be 30x 1 hour sessions.

Workshops: these will be held with the intention of being in a flipped classroom style as an opportunity for students to gain clarity of topics and reinforcement of previous learning. There will be 2x 2 hour sessions.

In exceptional circumstances (e.g., global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE, and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

Attendance Recorded: Yes

The student directed learning element of the module will involve directed reading, accessing online resources, searching the literature and critically appraising articles. This will require adaptability & organisational skills.

Liverpool curriculum framework and the Liverpool Hallmarks are at the centre of this module as evidenced by the cohesive research connected programme we have designed where learning outcomes will be evaluated with authentic assessments that directly relate to activities performed by professional experts in the field. This module contributes to a programme which is specifically designed to support students for future training in Biosciences – employability. For example, digital fluency is taught by data analysis and the use of online platforms. Research-connected teaching is embedded in all aspects of teaching as experts in their field teach the module.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g., global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE, and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
The module will be assessed via two assessments:

The first assessment consists of a multiple choice question examination with questions covering the content delivered in syllabus items 1-3 as noted above. It is worth 40% of the module.

The second assessment will be a 1500-word written exam assessment constituting 60% of the module. This will include tasks which require the analysis and interpretation of data and information relating to clinical and/or pre-clinical case studies within a pharmaceutical discovery and development setting.

Feedback will be provided to all assessments. Pass mark for all assessments is 40%. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission of all assessments. Assessments are anonymous.

Learning materials will be available to students via the University Virtual Learning environment.

Reassessment will use the same format, but the topic or data will differ. Mark will be capped at 40%. This will take place in the normal reassessment window. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g., global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE, and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

Outcomes

Learning Outcomes
 ReferenceOutcome 
 LO1 Discuss the basic concepts and theories relevant to drug design and appraise the critical issues determining success of drug discovery and development.
 LO2 Justify the choice of different target identification methods.
 LO3 Critically discuss the relevance of basic pharmacokinetic principles to achieving a good response to therapy and critically analyse pharmacokinetic data.
 LO4 Appraise the principles of drug disposition and drug response, particularly in relation to why subjects differ in their response to drugs.
 LO5 Justify clinical trial design choices.
 LO6 Appraise quality of evidence presented to regulatory authorities and cost-benefits of drugs.
Skills

Skills

 ReferenceOutcome 
 S1 Written communication
 S2 Critical thinking
 S3 Problem solving
 S4 Biological interpretation

The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
The module will be assessed via two assessments:

The first assessment consists of a multiple choice question examination with questions covering the content delivered in syllabus items 1-3 as noted above. It is worth 40% of the module.

The second assessment will be a 1500-word written exam assessment constituting 60% of the module. This will include tasks which require the analysis and interpretation of data and information relating to clinical and/or pre-clinical case studies within a pharmaceutical discovery and development setting.

Feedback will be provided to all assessments. Pass mark for all assessments is 40%. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission of all assessments. Assessments are anonymous.

Learning materials will be available to students via the University Virtual Learning environment.

Reassessment will use the same format, but the topic or data will differ. Mark will be capped at 40%. This will take place in the normal reassessment window. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g., global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE, and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

Outcomes

Learning Outcomes
 ReferenceOutcome 
 LO1 Discuss the basic concepts and theories relevant to drug design and appraise the critical issues determining success of drug discovery and development.
 LO2 Justify the choice of different target identification methods.
 LO3 Critically discuss the relevance of basic pharmacokinetic principles to achieving a good response to therapy and critically analyse pharmacokinetic data.
 LO4 Appraise the principles of drug disposition and drug response, particularly in relation to why subjects differ in their response to drugs.
 LO5 Justify clinical trial design choices.
 LO6 Appraise quality of evidence presented to regulatory authorities and cost-benefits of drugs.
